content: giant square scrap blanket by laura peters most knitters i know have a bounty of yarn scraps left over from completed projects or an abundance of minis from swaps and fellow yarnie friends what do you do with these scraps make a scrap blanket of course this project makes excellent use of all of the ​ ​ leftover yarn each new yarn is joined at the end of the one before it this pattern is fully customizable to your preferences you can make it big or small it s totally up to you it can be knit in whichever weight yarn you have the most of you can even change the type of increase it s knit in the round and there s no seaming or edges to pick up sizing & finished measurements yarn any size this is completely up to you fingering weight scraps of any amount suggested sizes other yarn weights can easily be baby- 30x30in/76x76cm substituted throw- 60x60in/152 5x152 5cm needles full- 80x80in/203x203cm us 2 5/3mm dpns and circular needles queen- 90x90in/228 5x228 5cm i have found my interchangeable set to be very helpful with this project gauge notions 30sts and 40rnds = 4in/10cm in 4 stitch markers tapestry needle for stockinette stitch weaving in ends ©laura peters 2017 1 abbreviations techniques used bobble - bind off working in the round ​ co - cast on basic increases ​ k - knit ​ pattern notes kfb - knit into the front and back of the stitch 1 ​ st increased tips are given throughout the pattern on technique pm - place marker ​ round s - round s ​ sm - slip marker ​ st s - stitch es ​ pattern using the long-tail cast-on method co 6 sts onto dpns or circular needle for magic loop method join for working in the round pm for beginning of round *tip use a unique marker for the beginning of round marker and plain ones for the other this helps you quickly identify where you are in the piece without much effort round 1 kfb all 12 sts round 2 kfb all 24 sts round 3 kfb k4 kfb pm 3 times kfb k4 kfb 32 sts round 4 k all round 5 *kfb k to 1 before marker kfb sm repeat from * to end of round 8 sts increased repeat rnds 4 and 5 until your blanket is desired size joining new yarn i used the overlap method for joining new yarn into my blanket for this method you overlap the old end and the new end knit 4 sts with both the old and new ends then drop the old end be sure that there are several inches of both yarns left hanging give a little tug to each end to tighten there are many methods for joining new yarn if you have a favorite use that one instead finishing loosely bobble all sts knitwise weave in ends block if desired for a more decorative
